title: Before 1 May 2018, will a ballistic missile defense system shoot at a North Korean missile launch?
possible_answers: Yes, and the North Korean missile flight path will be interrupted
Yes, but the North Korean missile flight path will NOT be interrupted
preds: No chance until Un meet Don
Given the meeting, no way they launch anything by May 1
We have three days and pending negotiations.

At this time in the international political environment, I don't see any actor engaging North Korea with a ballistic response to a missile launch. There is no real heightened tension at the moment with any other country that seems as though it would take such an aggressive stance towards North Korea, so I do not believe anyone will take this action anytime soon, especially since I don't even see a Korean missile launch on the horizon.

Since the likelihood of peace talks between the US and North Korea have increased, the probability that the North Koreans would launch a ballistic missile have dramatically decreased. Therefore, I think there is only a 1% that any defense system would have the opportunity to shoot down a North Korean missile launch.
North Korea made a public announcement that it would end missile and nuclear tests.

Three main reasons: 1] The time until the end of the month is short;  2] N. Korea has already made positive steps towards reconciliation with S. Korea, has had top levels meetings with China, and has already stated its intent to abandon its nuclear weapons program * (which could be a ploy ahead of a possible meeting with Trump), and, 3] The data regarding the U.S.'s 'missile defense system' is horrible (50% test failure rate even when given complete missile launch data [location, time of launch, and trajectory] of ALL 'enemy' missiles (source: Science/AAAS News, 2016). So, while we may indeed shoot at a NK missile (7 % chance of a NK missile launch, implied by the positive answer), there is a VERY low chance that we would hit it (probably closer to 100%). *to be accurate, the term reported in the News Media was "denuclearization", the complete meaning of which was /is debated (addendum May 18, 2018).

Kim Jong Un North Korea no longer needs nuclear tests
Jeong, S., Ripley, W. & McKirdy, E. (2018). CNN. World. Asia. Sat April 21, 2018. Retrieved from
https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/20/asia/north-korea-closes-nuclear-site/index.html
Time adjustment, meeting with Pompeo was made public.
Those on 100% for failed intercept will have a mega awesome score given consensus is 98-1-1! Holy guacamole Batman, it's deliciously tempting almost.
...because the n. Koreans in power know they would be annihilated after that, and when was the last time anyone had to interrupt such a launch?? (plus the deadline is very soon...)
Because Kim Jong Un is warming up across the globe (witness his recent visit to China) and his sister at the Olympics. And he hopes to meet with Trump soon.
Kim Jong-un may be an evil, power-greedy being, but I'm pretty sure he's not interested in an actual nuclear war.

With the state of North Korea as it is right now regarding various international tensions, especially when looking at North Korea and the United States, I think no country would be risky enough to take action against a North Korean missile launch, especially if the missile launch is a practice test and not an attack. This would seem, to me, to be an act of initiation of a conflict that could quickly become violent, and I don't think any country is willing to start this right now and possibly cause a much greater conflict in the long run.
There will be no North Korean missile launch

No launches have been intercepted to date. Time horizon is very short (only 3 weeks). Launches have slowed down recently. THAAD in SK is new but most missile tests fly over northern Japan. Decision to intercept is a provocative act by SK when currently in period of improving relations. NK is more unlikely to test right now given improving relations. So a launch of a NK missile is unlikely. US ability to shoot down missiles is about 2/3 I believe so presume Japan/THAAD is about the same. Therefore if launched, it's more likely to be shot down that not, but launch probability is unlikely to begin with, and launch of interceptor also unlikely.
With Nk now actively pursuing diplomacy and meetings outide their borders, it seems highly unlikely this would all transpire in the next few weeks.
Passage of time. Also NK appears to be moving to a more diplomatic stance.

Nth Korea are unlikely to make another test as sanctions are now biting and they want them removed. If they do test then there is no gain in intercepting the missile as it just gives Nth Korea information whether you are successful or not. The exception is if the missile comes to close and that's unlikely.

Things are going well for NK now. So they won't launch any missiles unless upcoming summits fall through or go very badly for them. Even if they launch, no one will shoot down as long as the trajectory puts the missile out to sea or something like that. Shooting it down or trying to would be an escalation.
The flight path

For someone to shoot at a missile there needs to be two things, 1. The North Koreans need to launch a missile, I've explained why I think that is unlikely below.  And 2. The missile needs to be aimed at a target. The reason no north Korean missiles have been shot at or down to date is because they havent been deemed to be targeted at a target such as a city and there is the opportunity to learn almost as much from their launch as they do themselves. 
The US can test their missile defense systems without showing their hands and firing at North Korean missiles. So to answer you have to answer is North Korea going to start a shooting war between now and May by firing at a target, even the most pessimistic would have to consider that unlikely at the moment.  In recent Months we have seen Kim move from outward belligerence to Diplomacy, they have won a small PR battle at the Winter Olympics, They have opened communications with the South and they are planning a meeting with President TRUMP.    
Kim visited Xie last month in Beijing, it is no secret that the Chinese would favor that Kim not rock the boat and antagonize the  US with missile launches. They are also said to have experienced some success with their missiles, so why keep testing. 
A test now would only anger the US and potentially create tensions at home. Hitler was all powerful but when a few generals etc thought they were being led down the garden path tried to kill him, there is no reason this couldn't happen in North Korea, although I admit the dynamics are different, any sort of major civil unrest would be incredibly turbulent, something I'm sure Xie would have emphasized last month. 
So I'm basing my prediction regarding shooting at a missile strongly to the North Koreans launching one, possibly a text book 'bait and switch'
Adjusting since the deadline is less than a month away.
what if the defense system does not bring down a missile - would seem to be a green light for further launches. Better to have it remain in doubt UNLESS it is targeting mainland US
The North Koreans have already achieved their desired endstate of possessing nuclear weapons and developing systems of delivery. I doubt that they will seek to escalate further unless provoked.
The mood seems to be moving towards diplomacy, rather than saber rattling.

1. It would be incredibly counterproductive for NK to launch a missile now. 2. Even if NK did test-fire a missile, it is extremely unlikely to be targeted at an area which is covered by missile defense systems. 3. In reality, there is a positive non-zero probability of a launch, but I view it as being so infinitesimally small that I am registering my prediction as 100% No.

The downside of a missed attempt is HUGE. It would demonstrate a defense system weakness - that may or may not exist. Much better to use defensive weapons only as required. (Consider the on/off success of the Patriot missile system and its affect on deterrence.)
would be strange if North Korea would launch a missile before May first given the positive things going on
N. and S. Koreas are in talks and Kim expected to meet Trump - thus nothing will done on either side to jeopardize that.
Recent events reflect a short term lessening of tensions between North and South Korea.
DKRP has nothing to gain with a missle launch during this time frame

I'm breaking this question down into two separate questions with eh first being  "Willa ballistic missile defense system shoot at a North Korean missile launch?" This question has two answers, yes & no. In light of recent announcements of talks between Kim Jong Un and President Xi and rumored future summit between President Trump and Kim Jong Un the fingers are probably off the trigger for the near future (including May 1). The second question would be "If a ballistic missile defense system shoots at a North Korean missile would the flight path be interrupted. With conflicting reaserch and reports I am leaving these options even for now, especially since it dosen't specify the USA meaning another conuntry such as Japan.

The reliability of the ballistic missile defense system is unknown. 
If it is used and doesn't work the political and finacial damage would be grave, Who will buy the system if it seems not to work with a high likelyhood? If it doesn't work countrys with ICBM will (re)gain political weight. Companys producing the defense system will loose value. But with Russias new Weapon Systems there is an alternative to the ICBMs and therfore the missile defense system are loosing value anyway.

Kim Jung Un is playing a silly tit for tat game with the super silly Donald Trump. KJU has his fun with the ballistic missile threats and he enjoyed the Trump knee jerk bluster. Now, KJU makes a new game: master deplomat! This stage of play will last at least 1 October 2018.
Updating for the passage of time. As this Q is closer to ending, the chances of this happening are less likely.
An interception constitutes an act of war. No party is interested in it until the meeting with Trump.
At the moment there isn't much bellicose talk so I don't think a missile launch by North Korea is likely within the time frame.

Inside factors:
- US/RoK exercises will commence in early April and this has in the past pushed DPK to respond.  So 67%.
- Kim is preparing for the summit with Trump and wants very much to let the Donald appear as the crazy man (see https://politicalwire.com/2018/03/04/quote-of-the-day-1869/).  So 10%.
Outside factors:
- I'm less sure here but my read of past interactions with Kim's father is that he was happy to behave and sign agreements and then immediately began violating them covertly.  Thus Kim Jong Un is likely to behave for now and then resume testing either covertly or launch a space program or similar.  So 1% but low confidence. Double weight the inside factors for a risk of 26%.  Intuitively this seems high to me but ...

Because the wild card has been laid on the table and the players on the opposite side (China, Japan, US) now know what DPRK's capabilities and limitations are. It is now time for the back door diplomacy to take its course so DPRK can gain whatever assurances it was seeking when it began this saber rattling exercise. Unexpected events might lead to a situation where DPRK is feeling left out again and they might fire another medium range poorly aimed non-nuclear payload test shot into the Pacific again - a situation in which both the US and China are best served to simply allow it reach it terminus in the water and not activate countermeasures for multiple reasons... which case would also fall into the "no" category on the wording of this specific question.

It's extremely unlikely that the US or its allies in the region would shoot down a North Korean ballistic missile launch by May. None of NK's recent missile tests have been intercepted by the US and its allies, primarily because, according to Sec. Mattis, those missiles did not pose a direct threat to the US. If this trend (NK testing missiles in relatively restrained manner) continues, standing US policy almost guarantee that intercepting a NK missile would not take place. Besides, given the recently shifted environment for US-DPRK and inter-Korean relations and the prospects of summit meetings in the near future, NK would most likely restrain its nuclear and missile programmes and might not test any missiles in the first place.
With the increase in positive relations between the Koreas and the USA there is definitley a decreased proabablity in rocket launches; let alone anti-missile missile defense.
Not expecting Korean missile tests before the purported meeting with Trump.

Given foreign deterrence and North Korea's history of threat and inaction, I believe that it is unlikely that North Korea will fire a missile in the first place, and therefore also unlikely that the missile flight will have to be interrupted.

Can't see North Korea  launching a missile prior to 1 may when there are the possibility of propaganda rich talks in the offing.  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/19/kim-jong-un-has-committed-to-denuclearisation-says-south-korea

With tensions seriously cooling down between North Korea and the rest of the world, specifically the US, and the talks between Kim Jong Un and President Trump looming, the North Koreans are highly unlikely to launch a missile at all, much less one that would be threatening enough to shoot down.  There is also the fact that the United States does not want to show its missile defense capabilities to other greater powers such as Russia and China. Even with this low possibility, nothing is impossible, and I leave the 5% on the table for "Yes". I give 3% to yes with flight path interruption because I assume American missile defense technology is superior to North Korean missiles, but I have heard that our defense officials are quietly not as confident as they'd like to be so I leave 2% with no flight path interruption.

The location of anti-ballistic missiles (such as Patriot, THAAD,  or Arrow) creates very small windows of interception and are not in place to address every possible ballistic path for a NK missile to take. For example a "polar shot" over China and Russia would have essentially zero interception ability, so an intentional "miss" into the Arctic would demonstrate an operational reach which could advance a political end, as long as China and Russia agree to have a NK missile fly over their sovereign territory which is a high probability if they see this as a valid way to distract the US or NATO away from other areas affecting Chinese or Russian interests.

Kim values the prospect of sitting down at the table with the US, so I think the chances of missile launches are greatly reduced.  If a missile or missiles are launched, they will likely continue the practice of being targeted at open sea. If a ballistic missile defense system is fired, success will be claimed absent undeniable success by the North Korean missiles.
Kim is talking instead of ranting, something significant is wrong in his missile program, so much so that he sees it more valuable as a bargaining chip than as an actual asset.
The Chubby Despot obeys fundamental rules of survival after all.
The US missile defense systems have shown a high degree of variance in their performance.
Similar reason when Japan could not respond to missile when it crossed its air region. US is not expecting and would hesitate to respond.
A temptation to shoot is high but not intercepting will be more devastating to US than intercepting to North Korea
Seems as though diplomatic channels are gaining traction. If meetings fail, look much higher probability of return to saber-rattling.
In light of recent discussions of trump and Kim meeting it seems unlikely that  North Korea would provide such an opportunity.

Kim Jong Un is highly unlikely to fire a missile at all in the near term. Even if he did, it's unlikely he would fire it in a direction/trajectory prompting a country to use its BM defence system. A country would not want to use that system for fear of confirming or denying whether their capability if effective.
Things seem to have cooled down. The planned meetings will take some time.  Decreasing odds to 0.
Kim is playing a long game. He is playing Trump.  I would have assessed the NO probability even higher, but with two erratic leaders in play, one cannot be sure.
It is unlikely that a ballistic missile will be launched near the time of the Presidential summit. Even if launched, it is unlikely to be shot at by any ballistic missle defense system
The US would not comptomise BMD capabilties for a test launch.
Unlikely to be any launches before the meeting between Kim and Trump.

Scaling up the probability from 90 to 98 as the inter-Korean negotiation sessions seem to be progressing stably - keeping a 1-1 uncertainty for outlier scenarios (given the past cycles of peace and conflict on the peninsula)

The base rate--no one has yet fired an ABM at a North Korean missile--for a host of reasons--argues this won't happen. But if the current positive signaling from the just-concluded Korean summit goes bust with a fresh confrontation, it's possible the administration would think that is the time to respond forcefully to a new round of missile tests. If they do, I could see the ABM missing, since the effectiveness there is no better than 50%. Which is another reason not to try  it, but with this President, who knows?

I have lowered the probability of a ballistic missile defense system shooting at a North Korean missile launch as a result North Korea expressing its willingness to negotiate with the United States on denuclearization. Kim Jong Un has also said that he will suspend all nuclear and missile tests during such talks. Moreover, the likelihood of North Korea launching a ballistic missile in the next 56 days in the first place has lowered. Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/06/world/asia/north-korea-south-nuclear-weapons.html

Until May, probably they won't launch any rocket:
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43296671
The U.S. will not risk the world seeing their missile defense system fail or miss.

"The United States is due to start joint exercises in early April"

Things would escalate very quickly after that
IF we took a shot, and it worked perfectly, the Russians would have a cow. We will avoid it.

To do so could provoke a full blown war. However, if during upcoming war games by the US, South Korea & Japan, were the North Koreans fire a missile, then allied retaliation could directly or indirectly occur. Otherwise not as likely.

I don't think nK will launch a missile before this date because I expect them to try to setup a meeting with the US, especially as sanctions start to bite.  If nK becomes pissed at the US for holding joint exercises with the South then they may launch another missile test.  Unless this threatens the US or our Allies I do not expect a missile defense system to be fired at the missile.
Updating this forecast to reflect recent overtures by DPRK towards diplomacy, making it even less likely that they would test.
Challenging the missile defense system has no win for the US as long as the missiles are targeted at the ocean and risks revealing technical weakness of defensive systems to other state actors.
I think, after the winter olympics, things are going to calm down a bit and diplomatic options will be explored.

There is almost no chance that N Korea will launch a ballistic missile before May 1, 2018 as anything but a test. Even a test launch by that date is unlikely. (30% chance). There is almost no chance that the US will attempt to shoot down a North Korean missile that has been launched as a test (even if there is a "bloody nose strategy"). In the very unlikely event of a of an attempted intercept it has approximately a 50% chance of succeeding.

I have very small reason to believe the North Koreans would do such a launch in the short term, due to peace process progress, however if they did anything significant, it would probaly be a test, not requiring a shot from a defense system, if a system where to shoot I believe it would succed
NK missiles unlikely to hit land, accidentally or not.

I see the firing of a missile and the missile being "interrupted" as an increased direct aggression, possibly leading to a spiral of counter actions. The consequences of these could have devestating results, which I do not think world governments would aspire to provoke.
This would represent a significant increase in hostilities and would likely be viewed as direct aggression and intervention in North Korean affairs.
The probability of a launch in this short timeframe is low, the probability of an interception is low as well as this would be seen as a massive escalation
Too much good will post Olympics to return to shooting rockets again so soon.

The implied question seems to be, what if anything may provoke NK into war (in the short term). To put it more explicitly, what calculus goes into pressure on NK, or an attempt on NK leadership (again, in the short term), or an all out "pre-emptive" military strike. If this is the intended question, why not ask openly? Article on this here: https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/24/seoul-worried-that-us-may-launch-preventive-strike-on-north-korea.html The question that is asked, is: would NK launch a test (why? They already demonstrated both nuclear weapons and missiles), and if so, would there be an intercept attempt (only near certainty of success would justify this). Combined probability near zero.

Thawing of relations reduces imminent risk. Shooting down a missile would be a significant evaluation too. If they do shoot, suggests they are confident of success, don't want to undermine the threat. Knock on implications from elsewhere if they do us the system too.
I think it might be closer to the SUMMER of 2018.
A missile attack by the north requiring destruction is unlikely to occur

This question is horrible (ie. poorly phrased). It is actually 2 questions: 
1. Will NK launch a missile by 1 May requiring interdiction? 
2. Given that a missile launch has occurred and requires interdiction, what is the probability that the flight path will be interrupted?  So y'all forcing us to respond to two questions with one answer. 1. I just have no confidence that we (US/Allies) are able to knock out any ballistic missile during any part of its launch phase. If i could have a assigned this a much lower weight, I would have. Second, I don't believe NK will start being belligerent so quickly after the Games. Maybe later this year.
May 1 is only 2 months away.  I think things might boil for that period of time before such a serious incident happens.  More likely later in 2018.

Neither side wants a nuclear confrontation, but there's always some chance of a diplomatic misstep that could cause one.  If so, it seems nearly certain that a missile defense system will be deployed, but it's a toss-up whether it will succeed.

The possibility of future launches is likely but any interception is not 100% reliable.  The deterrent effect of THAAD is more menacing against North Korea and China.  The plausibility of success or failure makes adversaries rethink the element of surprise because of second strikes.  The missile game theory equation might become the prisoner's dilemma, and the survivalability odds are slightly tilted in favor of South Korea because of THAAD.  More likely than not, striking is not a realistic option for Seoul (unless Pyongyang has a true madman).
Warning shots to make presence and observation known sounds like a good deterrent

The ballistic missile defense systems are designed to defend U.S. territory or that of an ally from incoming missiles.  What North Korea wants most is to preserve its regime and they know if they go on the offensive, they risk total annihilation.  Even under controlled test circumstances, a ballistic missile defense system has a 50 percent failure rate.  Thus, the US and its allies will not shoot at a North Korean test launch because the missile defense systems are designed to defend U.S. territory or that of an ally from incoming missiles and the “lofty” trajectories of some of the recent North Korean launches may complicate efforts to intercept the missiles.
Even if it happens and I lose the question I wont feel bad since I will get to "enjoy" the fireworks
It is likely that this will occur. The more interesting question is will this occur as part of a conflict or as part of a test.
This could serve as step one to broadening the conflict but it would be doubtful if the regional countries with capable Missile Defense assets would utilize these short of actual war time engagement.

Everybody is playing nice just at the moment.  It is, however, in the nature of moments that they pass.  Not sure Kim will fire off anything before April, and there if he does, there is some chance the US won't try to knock it down, lest Kim overreact.  It is a sad commentary on something or other that of the two most erratic children in the sandbox, The Pyongyang Kid is the more mature.
I think there is a possibility that continued Ballistic missile testing by North Korea will eventually provoke a use of force.
WWIII wont start as of yet
Updating based on relative quiet during the Olympics, shortening time-frame and possible rapprochement between North and South Korea.
Because there is a high probability of a miss.
I think it unlikely that DPRK will be that careless.
Someone might have a trigger finger.

Updating from 1/1/98 in view of recent NK diplomatic overtures. I think it means significantly lower chances of even any further tests, let alone any event that could trigger an attempt to shoot down their missiles.
Because of "warming" relations between North and South (caused by talks during and after Pyeongchang Olympics), NK will not shoot any missile before 1 May 2018.
hopefully the dynamics at the Olympics will be playing out for at least a while
I do not think North Korea will target populated areas that would trigger a defense response

North Korea has had several missile tests over the years, and not a single time has this happened. It remains highly unlikely for a number of reasons. This is a relatively short time frame, less than three months. North Korea's most active tests have historically been in the autumn, towards the end of the year. Lastly, the United States and allies would prefer not to demonstrate interception capabilities to the world unless necessary. Essentially, the only likely scenario of this happening is if North Korea went to war.
While there is an increase in ballistic system investments Chances are slim they will be utilized. North Korea isnt likely to test a missle where it would be intercepted.

It is unlikely for North Korea to launch a missile at a target that would warrant the response of a missile defense system. North Korea has launched its missiles mostly into the Sea of Japan. Moreover, something drastic would have to change for North Korea to launch a missile at an actual target in an act of outright aggression within the next 79 days.

DPRK  uses missile tests as a negotiation technique, and likely does not want to escalate to a hot war (they understand asymmetrical warfare does not favor their country). If they did fire a missile, it would be aimed at an unpopulated area most likely. Were  they to launch, western countries would stand to benefit from a successful strike on civilians, as it would justify force in retaliation. They either wouldn't or couldn't intercept.

Missile intercepts are questionable, and will be attempted only if a missile is headed toward a populated area (which would likely be as a result of a technical fault).  The US does not want to look impotent by missing an attempt.  PRK is currently riding high on a PR win at the Olympics.  The US is frustrated at this, but has more concerns with Syria unraveling, and a need to rebuild military hardware already.  The status quo of all players making noise and doing nothing will likely continue.

I'm updating this forecast after further research, with thanks to SMH5 for comments that caused me to reconsider and dig a bit deeper. It looks like DPRK has continued to test BCMs even after they began ICBM testing. One of their BCMs actually was shot down by China in the past, which is interesting. Between Feb 2017 and now, there have been 6 months when DPRK tested BCMs. They also had two tests of ICBMs. Between now and May, given this record, it is likely they will do so again. The Winter Olympics end in late February so they will still have March through May to test. So the question really is, will someone try to shoot it down? As mentioned, China shot one down but presumably DPRK will not fire in their direction again although China could choose to shoot it down as a show of their ability to do so. Unlike ICMBs, anti-missile defenses against BCMs appear to be rather advanced. South Korea has had this capability during the last few tests and has not shot one down, nor has Japan, nor have US forces stationed in international waters. If they choose to fire at it, it's likely they would succeed in shooting it down. Escalating tensions mean that they could choose to do so, but they haven't so far.
Lowering due to Kim Fatty III charm offensive
For this to happen, a missile would have to be launched that would take place near Japan, Guam, Hawaii, Alaska, or ROK. It is also reliant on more test firings.
PRK will not launch a missile attack

Frequency analysis of historical launch date suggests a 41% chance that NK would launch an ICBM in this window. Shooting an ICBM after has launched wouldbe a relatively safe "blood-nose". However, Japan's PAC-3 defenses will take until 2023 to finish deploying however, and other interceptors have too short a range to provide much of a window. The most likely intercept of such a test would then come from Navy ships in the Sea of Japan with only a 25% chance (estimated) of being able to shoot down the missiles.

Odds of a test prior to the conclusion of Olympics/Paralympics are low, given NK participation. Odds of tests after that date are difficult to predict, given the current set of circumstances. However, there are many factors that suggest that a shoot-down attempt is highly unlikely. Such an attempt would, in and of itself, be a provocation. It would also be very risky; ballistic missiles are difficult targets even for advanced SAM systems, and a miss would further embolden NK. In addition, the shootdown attempt itself, successful or otherwise, would likely provide the North Koreans with additional information about defense systems.  If there is a shootdown attempt, it will only be due to an off-target test attempt creating an actual risk to a populated area.

More countries' reviewing missile defence systems so slightly more likely to launch one. I say "slightly", but then again, someone did notify Hawaii of impending nuclear attack. The cynic in me wonders if that was actually a mistake or primary research about what would happen during a real alert. That area has a history of tests. Barring what I hope are a few extra steps to launch, the tail risk of a mistake in procedure for both warning and launch might not be so different
I'm updating my forecast due to easing of tensions going into the Olympic Games, and lack of recent launches
Slight raise due to Chinese ballistic missile test

Time is short. I see less than 50% chance North Korea will test again before May. The few indicators I've been able to read about suggest it's highly unlikely the U.S. , South Korea, Japan or China would be willing to pay the political cost of escalating tensions by attempting a shoot-down (though I'm less confident of that as I write). And I understand the prospects for success ahttps://www.gjopen.com/questions/668-before-1-may-2018-will-a-ballistic-missile-defense-system-shoot-at-a-north-korean-missile-launch#question_commentsre not very high:  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/10/are-us-defences-strong-enough-to-ward-off-north-korean-missiles

The likelihood of North Korea firing a missile at another country is slim to none, given the assumption that the concept of Mutually Assured destruction is well understood in high levels of North Korean government. Likewise, another country would only fire a counter missile if the initial firing was targeted at said country or one of its allies. While North Korea will likely fire test missiles, they will not warrant being shot down (which North Korea could potentially view as a sign of aggression on a test launch).

Due to the low success rate of the US ballistic missile defense and high enough likelihood of a globally watched embarrassing US failure / NK success, I don't think the US wants to shoot at anything other than dummy targets unless NK launched right at US territory or state...not at all likely in my opinion (NK already backed off from shooting near guam for fear of overwhelming retaliation). I also think that if the US wanted to stop a launch that they did NOT think was headed to their territory (i.e. to prove US could do it/ stop NK form getting more data from successful tests), then I think it is more likely to come in the form of a missile strike at the launch site prior to launch. Limit in US / SK intelligence other than from satellites introduces some uncertainty, as well as NK's claim to have vertically launching mobile missile launchers that are difficult to detect with satellites. But if NK surprises the US too well they may get an overwhelming conventional and / or nuclear response. I think Kim is pursuing the "goldilock's zone" by using the madman tactic enough to get SK to talk and the US to stop ignoring it, but not enough to make the US think they might really try to attack. After all NK are not terrorists or ideological fanatics, they are more ruthless totalitarian engineers.
South korea is the target and the us military is the most concentrated amount of damage possible within a very accurate range.
Laser tech is a wonderful thing.

ICBM interception is historically highly ineffective, hence the feverish attempts to develop lasers and other more accurate modalities. Testing a missile defense system and having it fail is worse than not testing it at all, considering that it's highly unlikely that DPRK would actually attempt to target another nation. There is no advantage to DPRK striking another country with an ICBM. While their rhetoric is inflammatory, they have historically acted in a rational manner when considering that most of their projection of power is meant to consolidate their own position domestically. While I'm hesitant to assign a zero probability, I consider this outcome highly improbable.

ICBM interception has shown very poor results. Hence the risk ICBM pose. Without a missile heading to US soil, the risk of attempting and missing and showing the lack defense capabilities is to great. And I put the chance of a missile being fired at the US near 0% before 5/1/2018
(downward adjustment as the time window for an accident decreases)
I think it is highly unlikely that we'll have a launch in the next three months, but if there is one, i think it is a toss up whether the US or Japan will tip their hands on intercept capability.
The North Korean participation in the Olympics will put any action off until March.  After that it is very unlikely, that this level of provocation will occur before May 1.
Tech not there yet.  But soon......
North Korea will launch another missile after the Olympics, which will be intercepted

Last year, North Korea launched 12 ballistic missiles. However, none of these tests were aimed at any of its regional allies with the intention of causing damage. It is unlikely that Kim will risk creating a larger conflict by launching a missile that would require interception by a missile defense system. It would especially be surprising for North Korea to do this in light of recently joining the Winter Olympics.

The Kim regime does not stand to gain from legitimate provocation opposed to bluster. However in the exceedingly rare event that a serious accident occurs, either THAAD or AEGIS have a high probability of kill against the system.

In considering whether or not a BMD system is going to take a shot at a NK missile launch, one would have to considering the opportunity, capability and intent of users with BMD systems. While the United States, Japan and South Korea possess a BMD capability, indications and warnings for a NK missile launch or test (opportunity) would likely be poor, which means that BMD assets would need to be forward deployed for unknown periods of time in a very tense environment. Given the geopolitical climate, it seems unlikely such a posture would be taken. Additionally, one would have to consider the ramifications of a BMD asset taking a shot at a ballistic missile and missing, which would potentially ruin BMD as a deterrent and possibly embolden North Korea (intent).  The odds of success with BMD decrease the farther missile intercept is attempted after launch. If assets are unable to take up advantageous positions in North Korean territorial waters, and if indications and warnings are poor, I think a shot is more likely to miss than hit.

Unlikely. An NK missile over Japanese air space would not lead trigger a missile response (capability is lacking). South Korea will not stoke tensions by launching a THAAD missile (a failure to intercept would be an immense propaganda victory for the North).

Since the North Korean launches have been for demonstration purposes and posturing, not attacks, the probability that they would initiate an armed conflict seems low. Also, initiating a conflict that they would ultimately lose, meaning the fall of the North Korean regime, would not serve the purposes of Kim Jong Il to remain in power as long as possible. Posturing and threats that give the North Korean regime room to operate and negotiate are a much more valuable use of their nuclear weapons then starting a war. The US and other countries know this too, so they are unlikely to shoot at demonstration ICBM's from North Korea.   As for the 50% chance of the missile flight being interrupted by a missile defense system, these systems have not been extensively tested, due to the cost and technical challenge of doing so, and the North Korean ICBM program has advanced more quickly than anticipated, so there is the potential that they are more sophisticated than analysts expect. These two reasons lead me to estimate a 50% chance of an intercept if one is attempted.

For the USA (or indeed any nation) to launch a missile defence system would be a significant historical event. Such an act would destroy deterrent precedent and profoundly destabilise the world. I believe that this is one reason why such an event is unlikely. The other reason is that I have doubts concerning how advanced N. Korea's capabilities currently are. Several failed tests, missiles breaking up upon reentering the earth's atmosphere, and a missile accidentally hitting a N. Korean city all suggest that N. Korea's tech is not that advanced. My YES probability exists largely due to recent inflammatory comments from the US president (including referring to Kim Jong Un as 'little rocket man') that appear to have escalated the animosity between North Korea and the USA. This is reflected in comments from political leaders across the world:  "We must stop a situation where North Korea miscalculates and threatens us with nuclear weapons or where the United States considers a pre-emptive strike." - Mr Moon (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/11/28/north-korea-fires-ballistic-missile-reports-may-have-landed/)  If world leaders are nervous that the USA might strike BEFORE being attacked by N. Korea, the chance that they will shoot a missile defence system is comparatively probable, as this would be a far less extreme action than a preemptive strike. I believe that if a missile defence system were used, it is more likely that it would not interrupt a flight path, based on current tests undertaken with these systems.
 (https://theconversation.com/explainer-what-is-ballistic-missile-defence-and-would-it-stop-a-missile-from-north-korea-80601). Such defence systems are at their most effective short range, and the sort of launch likely to trigger the use of a defence system would be intercontinental.
Delayed spring military exercises will either be cancelled or rescheduled after the Olympics, lessening the odds of an event in the near term.

Base Rate Analysis: Anti-missile weapons systems have had better luck in boost phase, than terminal phase, particularly with high apogee inbounds. Extent of NK decoys on ICBMs unknown. Uncertainty during boost phase about potential range of missile being launched. Aegis missiles have been upgraded.  While incoming missiles have been shot down elsewhere (e.g., Saudi), has not yet happened in NK. Specific Case Analysis: (1) NK would likely retaliate for shutdown; law of unintended consequences and escalation risks; (2) Potential implications (weakening of deterrence)  if attempted shoot down doesn't work; (3) Risk that NK might attempt a demonstration ICBM launch with air burst nuke; and (4) non-zero chance that Kim might try the real thing, as it were, though this would trigger massive retaliation (and he is likely more motivated by survival than a messianic religious belief). Conclusion: Unless there is intel that launch is an ICBM with a weapon payload, probability of attempted intercept is low. Especially given short time frame until the end of the forecast period. Pre-Mortem. Assue forecast conclusion is wrong. What did I miss? Trump's desire to demonstrate resolve, reduce perceived danger posed by NK ICBM threat.

First, I regard the odds of NK firing a real missile intended to strike an actual target before 1 May 2018 as well below 1%. So I'll focus on the case of a test missile like they've been firing all the time. I feel like firing at a NK test missile which is not meant to explode, nor is pointed at any target, would be an outrageous provocation, of the kind that everyone involved is very eager to avoid. Also the accuracy of these defense systems are well below 100% (even in controlled test situations, which is our only sample), and it would be extremely shameful, plus a massive victory for Kim, if someone tried to shoot down a NK missile and missed. If, on the other hand, the NK test missile was shot down, would that not simply justify Kim in pursuing his weapons program further --- indeed force him to? Which also nobody wants. He has already made numerous proclamations that "the NK nuclear force is complete". To bring some numbers into it: NK tested 16 missiles in 2017, of various kinds, not all amenable to being shot down by missile defense systems, e.g. due to short range. Given Kim's recent Olympics-related overtures, I think it's unlikely he'll do any more tests before the Winter Olympics are over, at the end of Feb 2018. That leaves 2 months before question deadline, so let's estimate (16/12)*2 ~ 3 missile tests before 1 May 2018. Even this is uncertain since as I mentioned Kim is making a big deal of his weapons being "complete". I'll call "no" a 98% and leave 1% for each of the others.
It seems missile interception systems deployed in the area have around 90% success rate, the overall possibility of an escalation of this sort is just plucked out of the air.

the project is not operational but unlike Thaad or Aegis  but after delivery of EMP to target
this abm missile, will splash down in sea
"It's called CHAMP, for Counter-electronics High Power Microwave Advanced Missile Project. James Fisher, spokesman for the Air Force Research Lab at Kirtland Air Force Base, said it's a high-powered microwave weapon that can be delivered on an air-launched cruise missile, deployed from an American bomber.
Fisher says the cruise missile with a CHAMP system strapped to it would fly into enemy airspace at low altitude, and send out strong pulses of electromagnetic energy. The enemy's electronic command-and-control systems would be jammed. Analysts say the cruise missile it's deployed on could then be splashed down at sea.
The Air Force says CHAMP was not developed specifically to counter the North Korean threat. But retired Gen. David Deptula, who once headed US Air Force intelligence, said the applications could be effective against North Korea"

"This section would require that, not later than 90 days after the date of the
enactment of this Act, the Director of the Missile Defense Agency, the Director of
Operational Test and Evaluation, the Secretary of the Army, and the Secretary of
the Navy shall jointly ensure that the test plans of the Integrated Master Test Plan
of the ballistic missile defense system prioritize the integration of missile defense
capabilities including Patriot, Aegis ballistic missile defense, and Terminal High
Altitude Area Defense (THAAD).
 The committee notes the recent emergency deployment of a THAAD battery
to the Republic of Korea to protect U.S. and allied forces against the rapidly
escalating ballistic missile threat from the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea.
While the committee supports this deployment, it remains concerned about
substantial delays to the integration of and coordination between THAAD and other
critical forward-deployed integrated air and missile defense systems, such as
Patriot. The committee believes it is imperative that the Department of Defense be
able to fully leverage forward-deployed missile defense assets as part of one
integrated system capable of discriminating, tracking, and defeating advanced
threats. Further, the committee believes that field commanders should have access"

updating:
1. taking a single launch by North Korea: 
(a) ICBM for technology development or demonstration, "safe" path: 80% chance of occurring; 2% chance of attempted interception; 30% chance of success for high angle re-entry in remote seas 
(b) "unsafe" path due to, e.g., error or military action: 6% chance of occurring; say 98% chance of attempted interception; 75% aggregate probability of success (varies by target missile)
2. multiple launch: most likely to include short/intermediate range missiles at SE Asian target(s): say 2% chance of occurring before May 1st, 2018; 98% chance a missile path will be interrupted; 80% chance at least one missile path interception will fail.

We have yet to have a ballistic missile defense system shoot at a North Korean. Therefore, the probability of it happening in the next half year is very unlikely. Though unlikely it is still possible due to an increase in tests by the North Korean government. If the defense system does fire on a North Korean missile launch then it will most likely hit the missile. In conclusion the likelihood of a ballistic defense system firing on a North Korean launch is very unlikely to happen due to no record of it in history. If it does happen it will also most likely disrupt the launch.

Well it depends upon what Mr. Kim shoots and where he is aiming. If Mr. Kim test fires an ICBM (Hwasong-14) the only device in the American arsenal that would have a chance to interrupt its flight path (and destroy it) woud be an Alaska based Ground Based Interceptor.  The targeted H-14 would be intercepted sometime following its boost phase and would likely be impacted over the Russian East, which would raise some serious questions from Moscow as to whether it was tracking a GBI or a hostile American ICBM (they will look the same on radar).  If the H-14 is fired towards Guam, impact would likely occur over the Pacific Ocean and be less likely to panic the Russians.  The GBI technology that is deployed would require 4 GBI interceptors to be launched to achieve a 97% kill possibility which is about 1/11th our our total missile force.  Missing the target would carry with it serious implications for perceptions of American deterrent capabilities, so it is likely that multiple missiles would be fired (perhaps as many as 6).  In short, this is a risky and expensive undertaking. Should NK fire an MRBM, it is possible that the THAAD or Aegis systems would be used.  THAAD systems have sucessfully intercepted MRBM at least three times with one test approximating battlefield conditions.   It is possible to launch multiple interceptors from SK, from US Navy platforms, and from Guan itself.  While hitting a NK MRBM is still difficult (and failure would undermine US ABM credibility), if fired over the Pacific there would be less downside to interception and a greater likelihood of use.   The questions must be answered with both scenerios in mind.  As the SK intelligence service has predicted a new wave of launches will occur before the year is out, there will be multiple opportunities to test these systems.  Should NK launch an ICBM, there is very little likelihood of an ABM response.  If a MRBM is launched towards Guam or over the Sea of Japan, it is much more likely that there would be an ABM reply.  Given the kinetic nature of these systems, I suggest that the missle path must be interrupted if fire upon because, as stated earlier, we can't afford to miss and will fire multiple interceptors. Much of the information used in my prediction came from https://warontherocks.com/2017/10/deadly-overconfidence-trump-thinks-missile-defenses-work-against-north-korea-and-that-should-scare-you/

The following are poorly-informed guesses, based on 1-2 hour review of publicly-available literature:
1. taking a single launch by North Korea:
(a) for technology development or demonstration, "safe" path: 25% chance of occurring before the main testing season; 25% chance of attempted interception; 50% chance of success for high angle re-entry in remote seas
(b) "unsafe" path due to, e.g., error or military action: 8% chance of occurring; say 100% chance of attempted interception (THAAD at re-entry); 75% probability of success
2. multiple launch: most likely to include short/intermediate range missiles at SE Asian target(s): say 4% chance of occurring before May 1st, 2018; 98% chance a missile path will be interrupted; 80% chance at least one missile path interception will fail.

The only systems that can currently shoot at a NK missile launch are the Aegis based BMD using the SM-3 bock Ia or IIa.  Currently the US Navy and the Japanese Navy deploy these missiles.  Range is between 700km and 2500km respectively.  Intercept rates appear to be high, but there have been misses some caused by human error.  However, success rates appear to be pretty high in tests, upwards of 90%. When asked why the USA has not shot at a NK missile, SEC Mattis said that none of the missiles were a direct threat.  As a policy this would explain why the USA and JAP have not targeted any of the missiles yet. So, let's rephrase the question--"Will NK fire a missile on a such a threatening trajectory that Japan or the USA will fire at it before May 1, 2018?" This requires for the USA that at least 1 x Aegis cruiser remains within range of launch sites in NK as there are limited other BMD systems available. There are advantages to letting the missiles go, intelligence collection is an important consideration.  The other is not risking a miss that the world would watch. There are reasons to shoot however, like demonstrating capability.  But the POTUS has not made a specific redline he'd be forced to heel to yet. I do not think that NK would do this because it does not improve their capabilities.  But there is a chance and I think that chance is 4% because NK's leader may think it is a rational thing to do. Information for this came from wikipedia's page on the SM-3.

THAAD installations and implementation has been completed in South Korea and Japan.  THAADs capability will allow it to intercept a missile in flight along its trajectory.  This question has more of a political flavor rather a military one.   Interception of NK missiles not directed at SK, Japanese or US targets will most likely will not encounter THAAD responses.  A political decision to intercept would have to account for all strategic interactions among actors along with a unitary response from target nations.   Attacks on targeted nation states would most likely have a high probability of a set of THAAD interactions with a reciprocal response from states in the alliance.  The question therefore becomes whether a strategic interaction would result in a path closer to an initiation of war (by all actors) or not.   A response, if chosen, would have to account for a ballistic missile armed or not armed with nuclear capability.  If a nuclear ballistic missile were encountered in the set of military interactions, a selected strategic response would initially include a THAAD interaction along with an ICBM response, initiating a response to war.  Given the high costs of war on human capital, military architecture and the outcomes of an ongoing conflagration  will result in significant costs for NK, its population, SK and it allies notwithstanding global outrage at the violent outcomes of war; these interactions could serve as a significant deterrent for all actors.   Lower level warfare to destabilize NKs military architecture and removal of its leadership is therefore significantly more likely than a set of nuclear interactions

Probably not; The Pyongyang Kid is not as crazy as lots of people seem to think.  However, the putative Good Guys won't shoot at anything they're unsure about hitting; the reputational cost of a miss would be fairly staggering even if the DPRK are just aiming at empty ocean.

While the question is whether or not a missile defense system will shoot at a North Korean missile launch, it may as well ask the question of the odds of military action between now and May 18th.  This is because following the missile over Japan in August, it was revealed that so long as the missiles are not on a trajectory to cause harm, the U.S. will not intercept them. As such, what is the probability that we will be headed for military action against North Korea?  I haven't the faintest idea.  However, a while back (early September) I went through the list of retired generals/admirals and researched what they thought the odds of military action against North Korea would be.   A Few Examples:  
- William Perry (Secretary of Defense):  "I think there's a 25-50% (and rising) chance of a second Korean War"
- James Stavridis (Retired Navy Admiral): "I think we are closer to a significant exchange of ordnance than we have been since the end of the Cold War...[snip]... The chances of a low-level conflict were even higher at 20 to 30 percent" Answers during interviews ranged from 0% all the way up to roughly 60%, with the median at ~25%.
